â€¢ What it measures: The ability to cover short-term liabilities with current assets.
â€¢ Why it matters: Indicates a company's short-term liquidity and financial health.
â€¢ Healthy range: 1.5-2.0 or higher.
â€¢ Your value: 2.5 â†’ This is strong, indicating excellent short-term liquidity.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Quick Ratio
â€¢ What it measures: The ability to meet short-term obligations using only most liquid assets, excluding inventory.
â€¢ Why it matters: Provides a more conservative view of immediate liquidity.
â€¢ Healthy range: 1.0 or higher.
â€¢ Your value: 1.7105 â†’ This is very strong, showing robust immediate liquidity.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Cash Ratio
â€¢ What it measures: The ability to cover current liabilities using only cash and cash equivalents.
â€¢ Why it matters: The most conservative liquidity measure, showing absolute immediate coverage.
â€¢ Healthy range: Generally 0.2 - 0.5.
â€¢ Your value: 0.6579 â†’ This is excellent, indicating very strong immediate liquidity.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Debt-to-Equity
â€¢ What it measures: The proportion of debt financing relative to equity financing.
â€¢ Why it matters: Indicates financial leverage and the risk associated with debt.
â€¢ Healthy range: Less than 1.0-1.5 is generally good, varies by industry.
â€¢ Your value: 0.811 â†’ This is healthy, indicating moderate reliance on debt financing.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Debt Ratio (Debt/Assets)
â€¢ What it measures: The proportion of a company's assets that are financed by debt.
â€¢ Why it matters: Shows the overall reliance on debt to finance assets.
â€¢ Healthy range: Generally below 0.4-0.6, depending on industry.
â€¢ Your value: 0.3043 â†’ This is very good, showing a low reliance on debt to finance assets.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Gross Margin
â€¢ What it measures: The percentage of revenue left after deducting the cost of goods sold.
â€¢ Why it matters: Indicates the efficiency of production or sales of goods/services.
â€¢ Healthy range: Varies significantly by industry, higher is generally better.
â€¢ Your value: 0.4 â†’ This is a strong gross margin, suggesting efficient core operations.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Operating Margin
â€¢ What it measures: The percentage of revenue remaining after deducting COGS and operating expenses.
â€¢ Why it matters: Reflects a company's profitability from its core business operations before interest and taxes.
â€¢ Healthy range: Varies by industry, but generally 10-20% is good, 20%+ is very good.
â€¢ Your value: 0.2667 â†’ This is a very strong operating margin, indicating excellent operational efficiency.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Net Profit Margin
â€¢ What it measures: The percentage of revenue left after all expenses, including taxes and interest, have been deducted.
â€¢ Why it matters: Shows the ultimate profitability of the company.
â€¢ Healthy range: Varies by industry; 10-15% is good, above 20% is excellent in many sectors.
â€¢ Your value: 0.2167 â†’ This is an excellent net profit margin, signifying strong overall profitability.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Return on Assets (ROA)
â€¢ What it measures: How efficiently a company is using its assets to generate profits.
â€¢ Why it matters: Indicates management's effectiveness in deploying assets.
â€¢ Healthy range: Generally 5% or higher is considered good; 10%+ is excellent.
â€¢ Your value: 0.2826 â†’ This is outstanding, showing exceptional efficiency in asset utilization to generate profit.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Return on Equity (ROE)
â€¢ What it measures: The amount of net income returned as a percentage of shareholders' equity.
â€¢ Why it matters: Indicates how well a company is generating profits for its shareholders.
â€¢ Healthy range: Generally 15-20% or higher is considered very good.
â€¢ Your value: 0.5118 â†’ This is exceptionally strong, demonstrating superior returns for shareholders.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Debt Service Coverage Ratio (DSCR)
â€¢ What it measures: The ability of a company's operating income to cover its debt obligations.
â€¢ Why it matters: Crucial for lenders to assess a borrower's capacity to repay debt.
â€¢ Healthy range: Generally 1.25 or higher is acceptable; 1.5+ is strong.
â€¢ Your value: 5.8667 â†’ This is outstanding, indicating very strong capacity to cover debt payments.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Asset Turnover
â€¢ What it measures: How efficiently a company is using its assets to generate sales.
â€¢ Why it matters: Indicates asset utilization and sales generation effectiveness.
â€¢ Healthy range: Varies by industry; higher is generally better; often 1.0 or higher is good.
â€¢ Your value: 1.3043 â†’ This is strong, suggesting good efficiency in generating sales from assets.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
---
ğŸ“Œ Inventory Turnover
â€¢ What it measures: How many times inventory is sold and replaced over a period.
â€¢ Why it matters: Indicates efficiency in managing inventory and sales effectiveness.
â€¢ Healthy range: Varies significantly by industry; typically 5-10 for retail, higher for fast-moving goods.
â€¢ Your value: 6.0 â†’ This is a healthy turnover, indicating efficient inventory management for many industries.
â€¢ If weak: N/A
summary_text:
ğŸ“ Summary
â€¢ The company demonstrates exceptional overall financial health across all key performance areas.
â€¢ Liquidity ratios are very strong, indicating robust short-term financial stability and ability to meet immediate obligations.
â€¢ Profitability margins are excellent, reflecting highly efficient operations and strong earnings power.
â€¢ Solvency ratios are very healthy, showcasing low financial risk and a strong capacity to manage and cover debt.
â€¢ Efficiency ratios, including asset and equity utilization, are outstanding, indicating highly effective management of resources to generate sales and profits.
â€¢ No areas of weakness are apparent; the company is performing exceptionally well across the board.
